dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is drab and the smell of old age lingers. ZAK (22), a young man with high-functioning Down syndrome sits in the lunchroom pushing food around on his plate. He shares a glance with ROSEMARY (92), who sits across th table. She looks down at a piece of paper in her hands, f it, places it in her pocket, and nods at Zak. Zak nods back and slowly pushes his pudding across the ta Rosemary eats the pudding, enjoying every bite. Zak looks around and sees senior citizens moving slowly. Wheelchairs and walkers surround him. ELEANOR (26), a kind brunette with understated beauty is dressed in business casual. She helps CARL (82) into his chair. Carl is gray all over and carries a cane; he flirt with the confidence of a man in his prime.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I like the cut of your jib darling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thanks Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Can I have those earrings? If I give them to Rosemary I think she might finally let me see what’s under that muumuu. Carl is pleased with his joke. Eleanor shakes her head an smiles. Eleanor moves around the room with the grace of a Kennedy she passes by Zak and Rosemary’s table. She adores Zak an love is palpable in her demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That’s sweet that you gave Rosemary your pudding Zak.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to be a really nice guy.  2. Zak follows Eleanor with his eyes as she exits the room a then looks to the exit sign above a door.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) Now. Rosemary places her hand on her heart and starts breathin loudly as nurses come rushing to her aid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door flings open and Zak comes sprinting out! He is followed by Eleanor and two male nurses dressed in white. Zak moves fast but awkwardly across the lawn; he stumbles over his own feet but keeps going. A smile creeps across face. BOOM! He is violently blindsided by another nurse. He nev saw the tackle coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TYLER (33), an adult Huckleberry Finn, wears a rubber apr made for fishing, a dirty white T-shirt, and a tattered r hat. He drives a crab boat through the Colington Harbor. He passes large commercial fishing boats, rusty cranes, a weathered fish packing houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler pulls up crab traps with Carolina blue buoys and sh his catch into large wooden boxes. Taped above his steering column is a sun-bleached photo o him and his big brother, MARK (38), standing next to an o pickup truck. Mark has his arm over Tyler’s shoulder. Tyler eyes a red buoy bobbing almost directly on top his one and checks the area to see if anyone is watching. With the coast clear he reaches down, flicks open a buck knife and cuts the line to the red one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler slows his boat upon seeing a North Carolina Fisheri Warden who has stopped to check another fisherman's catch Tyler then turns his boat and speeds away in the opposite direction. EXT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - DAY The two male nurses screw small gauge aluminum bars onto Zak's window then shake them to make sure they are attach securely. INT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - DAY Zak, still with remnants of dirt on his face, inspects an VHS tape carefully. He lifts the cover flap, and blows on magnetic strip. Zak places the tape into the player; it is labeled: “THE WATER REDNECK.” Sitting at attention on the edge of his bed, Zak watches footage of his favorite wrestler. THE SALT WATER REDNECK(34) wears blue camouflage briefs a matching face paint. His hair is long, luscious, blonde, held back by a rolled bandana that matches his briefs. Carl sits close by, with an afghan blanket draped over hi

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Lord knows if I had a nickel for every time you watched that video tape I would be a rich man. The video has high production value from the ‘80s, comple with star wipes and laser noises. Fans cheer as The Redneck roars like a lion and flexes in slow motion. The camera is close up on his sweaty face as he throws a grown man from the ring and a title flashes on the screen “ATOMIC THROW!” Zak opens and closes his hands in excitement.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER ON TAPE
dialogues.text: Some people claim the move is impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I challenge those people to define what possible is? I believe in myself. I know I’m the best, that’s why I’m the only wrestler that can do it. Simple as that. Zak looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We have watched that throw ten times today already.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I love The Salt Water Redneck. He is my hero, and he is a badass, and he is the greatest person ever.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And you will be the next badass!

dialogues.speaker: SALT WATER REDNECK
dialogues.text: (Directly to camera) Come to my wrestling school and you can learn the skills that it takes to be like The Salt Water Redneck!

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: (To Carl) I want to have the skills. Carl nods. On screen The Salt Water Redneck does a flip from the top rope and lands elbow first into the chest of his opponent Eleanor enters heated, carrying a clipboard. She turns the TV off and sits, balancing frustration and in her demeanor. Although her words seem cutting they are delivered tenderly. She loves Zak wholeheartedly.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You and Rosemary both lost all your privileges for the week.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Move Rosemary in here and I'1l keep an eye on both of them. Carl winks at Zak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a joke Zak, I'm labeling you a flight risk. Eleanor makes a note on her clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s twice now, two times. And you're getting other people in trouble with you. (beat) It's my job to keep you safe and you’re making my job hard. Eleanor holds up a drawing in front of Zak. It’s an energ and colorful self-portrait that depicts Zak with rippling muscles busting through a brick wall like the Kool-Aid ma On the bottom it says, “pudding?”

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this what you gave to Rosemary to convince her to fake choking?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's really creative.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Not just creative, it’s genius! You know why? That’s an advertisement for what he wants to do with the rest of his LIFE!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (easing a bit) You're a dreamer Zak, and I admire that, but the reality is--

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: --Eleanor, I am young and I am not old. Carl is old and we are different. Carl reacts to the jab from Zak about his age.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I wish I had a better option for you Zack. You don’t have a family that can that can provide adequate supervision. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The state has to put you somewhere and this is that place right now. Zak deflates.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (to Zak) You been here two years?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Two and a half years.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We gotta fix that.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eleanor, did you get me that soap I asked for? Eleanor hands Carl a container of liquid soap.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (To Zak) Stay on your best behavior for the next week, and you can get your special request privilege back too. Zak sticks his tongue out playfully at Eleanor and she do the same back. INT. WINKIE’S FISH HOUSE - DAY Tyler guts and cleans fish. A knife powerfully enters the fish’s soft fleshy underbel Blood and scales fly. He is working hard while listening to music coming from a crank radio. WINKIE (64), a kind-faced family man enters. He is sturdy from a life spent fishing crab pots and pulling nets, yet soft around the eyes and quick to smile.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: Tyler. Tyler is listening to music and doesn't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler! Tyler turns down the music on the crank radio.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey bud, Duncan and Ratboy are looking for you, you know what that’s about? Tyler goes back to cleaning. He tears the spine out of th red drum (a meaty game fish found in the Atlantic).

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I could speculate a guess.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: Them boys are pit bulls, don’t mess with them.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Maybe they messed with me. Tyler is focused on the task at hand. His knife removes t head and tail of the fish with two confident chops. Winkie looks on, saddened by Tyler’s demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: That’s it for the day, bud.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You said I could clean all the fish you were gonna send to market?

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: That’s it, that’s all of ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I need a job Winkie, I barely cleaned one bucket of drum. You gotta have some snapper or sheep’s head for me?

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: Not biting right now, bud. You better just go. EXT. BOAT DOCK OUTSIDE WINKIE’S FISH HOUSE - DAY Tyler solemnly sits on a railroad tie overlooking the mar  8. Winkie brings a peace offering of a cold beer and sits be him.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Thanks, Wink.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: There’s only so many commercial tags to go around. You can’t help it that Dunc and Ratboy scooped up Mark’s as soon as he passed. (beat) I can’t have you bringing me fish caught without a license bud. I get caught and it’s my ass, not yours.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do? I would have bought it if--

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE
dialogues.text: --Get your life together, get it in order. Mark would be proud of you if you did that. He’d be very proud of you if you did that. Winkie stands to walk away and leaves Tyler alone with hi thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin flashback music. Tyler and his big brother MARK scrub barnacles off the bo of their boat raised up in dry dock. Mark is fit and tan and his clothes are faded by years of exposure to sun and salt water. He is clearly the alpha o the two and smiles as he playfully sprays Tyler with a ho Conversation is had but words can not be heard. Mark cracks a beer, goes to his pickup truck and pulls ou wrapped gift that is shaped like a baseball bat. Mark hands the present to Tyler. Tyler looks at Mark with admiration and takes it. Tyler unwraps an older, used, but beautiful, shotgun. Mark ruffles Tyler’s hair as he looks the gun over.  9. Mark runs his fingers over the wood that is branded “Fami First.” Tyler smiles and thanks his brother. They hug with a lovi masculine embrace. End flashback music.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT
dialogues.text: INT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - NIGHT The lights are off and Zak sits on the edge of his bed on again watching his Salt Water Redneck VHS. Flickering light from the TV illuminates his face and highlights the edges of the bars freshly installed outsid his window. He is a prisoner now. One of the male nurses from earlier pokes his head throug the door.

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Lights out, retard. The nurse flicks the lights off. INT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - NIGHT Zak lies on his bed, staring at the ceiling. The clock re 3:21 AM. A hand reaches out to wake him, it’s Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (whispering) Hey son, get up. I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Carl stands in front of the bars on the window. He tears pieces of bed sheet and wraps them around two of the bars

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Did you know I was an engineer in another life? I was. Zak watches Carl, amazed. Carl places his cane between the strips of sheets. He beg to rotate the cane, reeling in the slack in the fabric.  10.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, you're strong, you do this. Zak takes his place. He spins the cane and the fabric pul harder on the bars.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good, that’s it there. The bars slowly begin to bend together. Zak strains as he turns the cane another rotation.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now move down and do it again. (beat) A bird in a cage ain’t really even a bird. God gave you a gift. It’s a shame people don’t know how to let an animal as beautiful as you fly. Zak continues his work and the gap between the bars grows Carl smiles and hands Zak the bottle of liquid soap that Eleanor gave him earlier. He holds Zak’s hands between hi Zak smiles and looks down at the gift.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Carl, you are my best friend, and you are my family.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Well that’s it. Friends are the family you choose.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: And Carl, you are invited to my birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Thank you, I’m there. Carl kisses Zak gently on the forehead; they hug goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now go kick some ass. Zak, takes his pajamas off. Carl slips into his bed and closes his eyes. The poster of the Salt Water Redneck that hangs above Zak bed looks down approvingly.  11. Zak stands only in his tighty-whities illuminated by moonlight. He looks at the compromised prison bars on his window, in on doing it right this time. He begins stretching like a weekend jogger. He touches hi toes and stretches his torso from side to side. He takes a few deep breaths, nostrils flare. He cracks his neck and hits his chest with a closed fist. He picks up the bottle of Carl’s liquid soap and squirts into his hands. Zak lathers up his stomach, his back, and arms. Finally, he puts it all over his face. He reaches out and grabs the bars... .+.-puts one leg through easily... .--his torso hits the bars and stops. Zak groans and forces his body through the opening. His face, still not through the gap, smashes together mak his lips purse. He breathes harder. His skin bunches up, glistening from the soap; as it give way, he slides through the bars. Zak grins, and takes off across the lawn. Carl smiles and waves goodbye from behind the bent bars. Zak is running across the lawn in slow motion. He glisten the moonlight. EXT. BOAT DOCK OUTSIDE WINKIE’S FISH HOUSE - MORNING Zak, still in his underwear from the night before, enters boat yard timidly. He hears a door open and dives behind a large stack of cr pots. Tyler exits the fish house, wearing cut off jean shorts a white T-shirt. Fish blood and scales cover his hands and torso. DUNCAN (49), a wiry fisherman with sure blue eyes and the strength of a man twice his size immediately shoves Tyler into the stack of crab pots that Zak is hiding behind.  12. Duncan’s hands are callused from honest work, and leave grease marks on Tyler’s shirt upon impact. RATBOY (27) and CRAIG (39) round out Duncan’s posse, they nearby on open tailgate of his camouflage diesel truck watching as the scene develops. Ratboy is rail thin, covered in tattoos, and looks sickly with graying teeth. Craig is unforgettably obese and laug with a high pitch chuckle that cuts above the noise.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You cut the buoys off my pots? Duncan grabs Tyler violently by the collar. Tyler’s fists by his side, ready to be used if needed.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You cut them buoys?!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: We've been laying our pots on the Powell’s Point for years, Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Fuck him up, Dunc!

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Powell’s Point WAS Mark’s, but Mark is gone. It was his fishing license too, remember?

dialogues.speaker: RATBOY
dialogues.text: You cain’t fish there no more!

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Bring back so much as a minnow and I’ll have the Game Warden cart your ass to prison. You’re done crabbing in Colington. This ignites Tyler’s anger and the two start to fight. Zak crawls along the pots trying to get away from the mel Duncan, much better with his hands, hits Tyler with one powerful punch to the gut and drops him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tyler) There's 10 fishing licenses to go around Dare County.  13. Duncan pulls out a piece of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one used to be Mark’s, but it says Duncan Silver now. (beat) That's just business. Ratboy gets off the truck and walks toward Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You owe me 40 pots. Duncan walks toward his truck and points to a large stack crab pots adorned with red buoys.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Touch my rigs again and you better grow eyes in the back of your head. I ain’t jokin’ either. I’1l bash your skull in with a tire iron. Ratboy drops down and puts his hand on Tyler’s throat who still laid out in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: RATBOY
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) You cain’t fish, sure as shit cain’t fight, whatcha still doing in Colington? Ratboy hawks up a loogy and spits it on Tyler's face.

dialogues.speaker: RATBOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as he walks away) That's right, someone gotta clean all those crabs we gonna be bringing in. Zak climbs down into Tyler’s boat and pulls a tarp over h head to hide. INT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - DAY Eleanor, in a state of complete shock, looks at the compromised bars on Zak’s window. She breathes deep.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Shit. Carl is lying in bed watching; Eleanor turns to address h  14.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well where did he go? Carl looks guilty and shrugs sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got answers and you’re going to give them to me one way or another. JANICE, (42) a strong and vibrant African-American nurse middle management pops her head into the room. She wears hair in long braids featuring colorful beads that touch t small of her back.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: E, Glen wants to see you in his office. (as she walks away) We are so fucked.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thanks Janice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler sits in silence leaned against a wooden piling, dir and blood still on his face. From the pocket of his shorts he pulls out an old plastic filled with dirty cigarette butts and rolling papers. After placing a rolling paper on his lap he harvests toba from five cigarette butts; hand rolls, licks, and lights a match. As he smokes Tyler eyes Duncan and Ratboy’s crab pots wit their red buoys. He goes to his boat and fumbles around looking for someth He almost pulls the tarp off Zak, but at the last second, grabs a large red canister of gasoline. Tyler pours the gas all over Duncan & Ratboy’s buoys. He contemplates for a moment, then tosses his cigarette d immediately setting the gasoline soaked pile ablaze. His eyes widen as the fire starts to take over more than the buoys. Every crab pot Duncan owns is now on fire.  15. Tyler, nervous, gets in his boat, puts the key in the ignition and turns it. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Shit. Tyler turns the key again, nothing. Men yell in the distance as the light from the fire flick and highlights the concern on Tyler’s face. Tyler turns the key again and the engine, a single 90 hor power Yamaha, spins but doesn’t start. Duncan and Ratboy approach fast. Tyler turns the engine again, it chokes and sputters. Once more he turns the key and it starts reluctantly. The running lights on the boat all come to life. Tyler punches hard on the throttle and spins the wheel ju as Ratboy and Duncan are getting out of their pickup. Duncan and Ratboy run toward their boat to chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT BETWEEN DUNCAN’S BOAT & TYLER’S BOAT. Tyler is far out in front, but Duncan and Ratboy are gain ground. Duncan and Ratboy’s boat has two 200 horsepower motors, a they run clean and fast. Tyler takes a hard turn into a maze of tall marshy grass an attempt to lose the larger boat. Zak, still hidden under the tarp, is getting tossed aroun like a rag doll. Tyler weaves through the reeds like an old pro. He stops and throws the engine abruptly in reverse. He ba into a concealed spot in the grass barely wide enough for boat. Quickly, he shuts the engine off. The motor goes silent a the running lights go dark.  16. Tyler looks anxious but remains quiet. Ratboy and Duncan look around, they’ve lost Tyler in the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: He's here somewhere. Zak, seasick from the chaos of the boat ride, starts to grumble. Tyler, startled by the sound, tears the tarp off the stowaway just as Zak starts to dry heave and then vom loudly. Ratboy tilts his head like a hunting dog.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhhh... Duncan shuts off his boat, and they sit in silence for a moments... They hear Zak’s vomiting.

dialogues.speaker: RATBOY
dialogues.text: There! Tyler, furious and scared, covers Zak's mouth but the retching isn’t finished. Vomit oozes above and below Tyle hand and between the fingers pressed hard against Zak's f

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Who are you?! Zak pulls Tyler’s hand down from his mouth to speak.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I’m Zak. Duncan’s boat approaches. Tyler quickly and confidently starts the engine and gasse it, pulling his boat out 100 feet in front of Duncan's. Duncan and Ratboy gain on Tyler as they both hit open wat The lights on Tyler’s boat are becoming noticeably closer

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You got nowhere to hide now. Tyler is driving fast, water slaps loudly at the hull. Ni is approaching. He looks over his shoulder, Duncan and Ratboy are getting closer.  17. Tyler tears his shirt off and uses it like a rope to affi the steering wheel to the compass so the boat doesn't tur He then grabs a hammer and smashes out the running lights by one.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fucker. Tyler's lights disappear completely. Duncan slows his boat and stares into the darkness. INT. RETIREMENT HOME - GLEN’S OFFICE - NIGHT GLEN (57) sits across from Eleanor. He is small in statur oily, and balding. He has the look of an unkempt man and clicks his pen angrily over and over while looking at Eleanor’s clipboard. His office is filthy. He reads for a few moments, then flips a page over.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: A flight risk? Eleanor nods her head yes.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looks like all that family money of yours bought you a degree but didn't get you no common sense. Eleanor shifts nervously and subtly moves her hair to cov her diamond earrings.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but my family history has nothing to do--

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Don’t speak. Eleanor bites her tongue.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You let a half naked boy with Down syndrome who has no money, no family, and no idea how to get along in this world just slip out from under your nose into thin air. Eleanor remains silent.  18.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you have no idea where he is, where he’s going or who he might be with?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well I have--

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: --The nurses tell me you two are close.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Then you'll figure out where he’s at and bring him back before I have to report this to the state.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No Glen, you have to report this, he’s missing.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler's boat is beached a few feet away from where he sit the sand with Zak, the two silently study each other. Zak is still in his tighty-whities and looks filthy. Tyler is still covered in dirt and blood.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Why were you on my boat? Zak does not answer. Tyler continues to stare.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cat got your tongue? Zak still does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You running from something? Zak stirs a little at this comment.  19.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got something to hide? Zak looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s it, isn't it? (beat) Well, that’s your business. EXT. TYLER’S BOAT BEACHED ON THE SAND ISLAND - DAY Tyler turns the engine, it screeches and whines, metal bi metal. Smoke plumes from the vents. The pistons have seiz Tyler, a true water cowboy, isn’t fazed. On to the next. He moves fast and starts throwing things from the boat on the beach. A backpack, some fishing line, duct tape, an o pair of white rubber fishing boots, his crank radio, an e pair of clothes, some prepackaged food you might find at gas station, a long cord of rope, and a canteen. These things land close to Zak, almost hitting him. Tyler pauses a moment to look at the photo of Mark and carefully puts it in his pocket. He grabs a 12 gauge shot and a box of shells. Zak looks worried. Tyler loads the gun and unleashes three blasts into the floorboards of the boat. Zak flinches and covers his ears. The boat begins to sink. Tyler begins to pack up his gear.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You got thirty minutes till the tide comes up and this whole place is under water. He walks past Zack along the sand bar. Zak follows, fumbling to catch up, tripping over his feet

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Umm... Why did you do that?  20.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Covering my tracks.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Oh, OK. (beat) Ummm... Where are we? Tyler doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) See... Um... I don’t know where I am, so I don’t know how to get where I’m going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler reaches the shallows and starts to wade through the knee-high water. Zak stops timidly at the water’s edge an looks out at Tyler who is still moving.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no. (to Tyler) Umm... Excuse me... Excuse me? Tyler turns and looks at Zak.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, umm... See, umm... I can’t swim. Will you please help me? Will you please be my friend? Tyler watches. Zak slowly begins wading through the water toward Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (upon reaching Tyler) OK, I’m OK now. Zak gives Tyler a thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You following me? Zak shrugs and sighs, then nods his head yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know where Manteo is? Zak shakes his head no.  21.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have any clean water? Zak shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you fend for yourself at all? Zak looks ashamed. Tyler hands Zak a canteen of water, Zak chugs it, then ha it back. Tyler starts to walk away and Zak follows.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I can leave you, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler walks in front of Zak, who hangs on his heels like puppy -

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: .-.and then The Salt Water Redneck throws people, it’s called the “Atomic Throw”! Zak mimics the Salt Water Redneck’s signature move as he out a feeble attempt at a roar. Tyler continues walking; he doesn’t engage in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to Ayden, North Carolina to learn the moves... (beat) Zak pumps his arms in the air and makes a cheering noise.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And they might say, “Zak you are so awesome. You are a bird. You are the most free bird ever.” Zak squeezes his hands excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah! Tyler stops and faces Zak, which abruptly shuts him up.  22.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You're walking real close to me. Zak takes two small steps backwards. He looks at Tyler as to say “OK, is this enough?” The two start walking again. It is quiet for just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: And I am going to live in a big house with lots of snacks and drinks and I’'1l have an airplane--

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: --Does your family know where you are?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: My friends know where I am. Tyler takes out a granola bar from his backpack and takes big bite. Zak watches, almost drooling. Tyler glances over his shoulder and notices Zak watching but keeps eating. Zak's pale skin is turning pink from the sun.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Not worried about a sunburn, huh? INT. RETIREMENT HOME - ZAK & CARL’S ROOM - DUSK Eleanor watches Zak’s wrestling VHS intently, putting together clues and connecting the dots. The “ATOMIC THROW” title card flashes.

dialogues.speaker: SALT WATER REDNECK
dialogues.text: If you come to my wrestling school in Ayden North Carolina I will teach you the skills... Eleanor writes “Ayden” with permanent marker on the palm her hand. Her face shows worry about where Zak might be, how she ca find him, and if he’s safe.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children are playing at a redneck water park. The structu is a huge mess of scrap wood rising sixty feet above the water. It has a handmade Water World vibe. A boy of 14 does a back flip from the top platform.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: End of the road. Zak watches another boy do a gainer off the top.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know my name?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Good. You never saw me, OK?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey... Can I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Why would I need you to come with me?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Maybe we could be friends, buddies, roll dogs? And hang, and chill, and have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Don’t go getting yourself killed. A brief but warm moment is shared here. Zak waves as Tyle walks away. Zak walks toward the group of boys on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Do you guys like birthday parties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler walks alone beside a cornfield and picks a cigarett butt off the ground.  24. He hears the sound of an engine approaching and puts his thumb out. A truck pulls over just in front of him and Tyler picks u his pace to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler rides along side of a TRUCKER (54) in an older mode Chevy pickup truck. There is a happy, beat-up, mangy, one eyed dog sitting in between them. The two men sit in silence for a while. The mangy dog pants comically close to Tyler's face.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: He a good dog?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: She’s good enough. (beat) She don’t run away, so I guess that makes her mine. Wife’s long gone, and my kids are grown. (beat) We look out for each other.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What’s her name?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: She ain’t got one. I just... The trucker whistles three short notes. TRUCKER (CONT’D) ...and say, “Come here dog!” And, she comes.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Seems like a good dog.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: She’s good enough. The trucker rubs the dog’s head. TRUCKER (CONT’D) Crazy ain't it? That fire down at the docks? Tyler takes notice but tries to hide his concern.  25.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear much about it. (beat) What are people saying?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: Started off small, got out of hand pretty fast. (beat) Some of them boys are out right now looking for the guy that lit it. They set up a road block on 158. Tyler soaks this in. Red lights flash below the railroad crossing sign ahead a the gate lowers. The truck comes to a stop. Tyler plots his next move as the train passes by. After a moment he opens the door and exits the truck. TRUCKER (CONT’D) Sure you don’t want a ride all the way into town? I’m going right there. The dog licks toward Tyler’s face through the window.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (beat) Nah, I left something back there. Tyler watches the truck drive away. He then turns and duc into the cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler walks toward the docks where the boys were playing earlier; he hears taunting. Zak has climbed up to the tallest platform and the older are causing a scene. A FAT BULLY (12) stands next to Zak on the platform fifty feet above the water.

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: Jump retard. Jump! Zak peers over the edge.  26. FAT BULLY (CONT’D) Durr durr durr! I thought you were a retard not a pussy! Jump, you retard!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (yelling up the bully) Hey, he can’t swim.

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: (to Tyler) Like I care dipshit. Tyler drops his backpack and climbs up the platform hand- hand. FAT BULLY (CONT’D) Do it! Jump!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I said he can’t swim.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I am not going to do it. The bully pushes Zak off the platform. His body hits the water hard and immediately sinks. Tyler makes it to the top and walks to the edge of the platform. He stares down waiting for Zak to reappear. Only bubbles rise to the surface.

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: Shit man, that dummy sank like a rock.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Come on... Tyler starts taking his shirt off.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that, 20 feet deep??

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: Twenty five at least.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: How strong’s that current?  27.

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: Running ‘bout four knots south. Tyler takes that in and cracks his knuckles. FAT BULLY (CONT’D) Hey... you’re the guy that cleans fish over at-- Tyler punches the boy in the face, then jumps in after Za Beneath the surface Tyler swims downward into the darknes the murky water, wraps his right arm around Zak’s limp bo and begins his ascent toward the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zak coughs up water as Tyler sits next to him soaking wet

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: So there’s a wrestling school in Ayden?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: And they teach you full-on, legit, WWF moves?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: What does legit mean? Tyler takes out a map from his bag and unfolds it on the beach so Zak can see; he tracks his finger with his words

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: We’re in Manteo, right here. (beat) And this is Ayden, 70 miles from here. That’s where the wrestling school is you're talking about. See that, it’s on my way. The map shows Ayden at the end of a long narrow barrier island with only one road running its entire length. (beat) And then this is Florida. (beat) That’s where I’m going, Ayden is on my way.  28. Tyler puts the map in his bag.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You bullshitting me about this wrestling school? You swear to god? Zak holds up his right hand as if he is testifying in cou

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yes, I swear to god. I have proof of the video tape.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Alright, I’1l drop you there then. I ain’t doing no charity shit, it’s just on my way. Tyler pulls an old greasy black Grave Digger monster truc shirt from his backpack and throws Zak. Zak stands and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: What is your name? Tyler turns to face Zak.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: That is a very cool name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor shows people the photo of Zak and asks if anyone seen him. They shake their heads “no.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor knocks on a series of doors searching for Zak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SUBURBAN HOUSEWIFE (52) stands at her door.

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: He’s young, what’s he doing in an old persons home?  29.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It’s pretty common for people with disabilities like Zak to be placed in a nursing home, no matter what their age is.

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: That seems odd.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is a little odd isn’t it? (beat) If you see him can you give me a call? Eleanor passes a piece of paper with her phone number thr the crack in the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Duncan leans against his truck and watches Ratboy in the distance slapping the Fat Bully in the face.

dialogues.speaker: RATBOY
dialogues.text: Which way did he go?

dialogues.speaker: FAT BULLY
dialogues.text: I told you I don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak walk hidden from the road through cornfield Tyler leads. Zak gets hit in the face by leaves as they move.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: My Feet hurt. (beat) Tyler, do you have a car? Tyler does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tyler, can we please walk on the road?  30. Tyler, frustrated, turns to face Zak.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Will you please answer me?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, my brother and I were camping off of Caffey’s inlet, and there was this big ol’ hornet’s nest right by the water. I just strolled over to it and boom, hit it with a stick like a baseball bat, home run. I got stung bad and my eyes swole shut. Mark was pissed. He said, “Keep stirring up shit, get yourself killed.” (beat) A little older. Little wiser. Not much. I’m still whacking hornet’s nests. (beat) You ever kick a hornet’s nest?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yeah, last night. Tyler is surprised by Zak's answer.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You hit a hornet’s nest last night?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Last night.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Well, then you understand why I can’t walk on that road right now. Stop with this “Tyler” shit, we're gonna be quiet the rest of the way. Tyler turns around again and leads Zak through the corn. Silence and walking.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Tyler... Tyler's frustration boils over; he turns to face Zak agai

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Finish what you got to say and then we’re gonna walk on in silence. Tyler! Tyler! Tyler! Tyler, What?!  31. Zak's tone turns serious.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I want you to know about me. (beat) I am a Down syndrome person. Tyler takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I don’t really give a shit. You got supplies?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: No. The two set off again through the corn.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: We’re gonna need some supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zak and Tyler, peer through cornstalks at a dilapidated country store / gas station surrounded by farm land.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: How much money you got?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Oh, I got no money, and I got no pockets. Zak still wears tighty-whities and the shirt Tyler gave h Tyler gives Zak a pair of camo pants from his bag.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go and grab some essentials.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brass bell above the door rings.  32. The CASHIER (77), an old, gray and frail man wearing Coke bottle glasses, watches Tyler enter. Tyler has his backpack on with the shotgun slung over his shoulder and dried blood on his shirt. The Cashier looks on nervously from behind the register. Tyler walks around the store filling up a basket with pea butter, fish hooks, fruit by the foot, Ding Dongs, a pre- sandwich, and Spam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cashier slowly adds up the items by hand with a penci He is the embodiment of a turtle and speaks with a cadenc match.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: That’1l be thirteen dollars, and eighty-three cents.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Son, that sandwich alone is four dollars and your Ding Dongs they're two dollars a piece... and that’s another dollar thirty five-- Tyler separates the fruit snacks and the Ding Dongs.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: --How much for just that?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Three dollars and we’ll call it even.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: That'll work, just the peanut butter and the fish hooks.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Son, forgive me if I seem alarmed but I don’t normally negotiate on my prices with fellas that have shotguns laid across their backs. Tyler removes his backpack and shotgun to ease the tensio  33.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank ya kindly.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You got any airplane bottles of whiskey back there for two dollars?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: No... but I got this. The cashier grabs a large unlabeled dirty jug of liquor f under the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I can’t afford that.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: This bottle’s on me, son. Looks like you might need it more than I do. I’1l just have me a splash to calm my nerves. The cashier’s hands are shaking as he takes a swig. He hands it to Tyler who does the same. The bell above the door sounds again and Eleanor enters. Both men take notice.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma’‘am.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Ma’‘am.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. Eleanor picks up a bag of M&M’s and approaches the counte

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Missy, I'll have to ask you to forgive my elongated stare. I haven’t seen a woman as pretty as you since I cain’t remember when.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) Where did you blow in here from? She sizes him up before answering.  34.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You graduate JMU or GW?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, you've got that kind of look about you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What kind of look is that?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You know, just an excited to be alive kind of look. What you doing down here?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're quite nosy.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I like to think I’m inquisitive with a side on interested.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Interested huh?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah... you interested? Tyler lifts the bottle to offer her a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I told you, I’m working.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You work crab boats? Tyler begins laughing at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: See it’s funny because you don’t look like you would work on--

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I know why you think it’s funny.  35.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re trouble. Eleanor pulls a photo of Zak out from her purse and holds up for the cashier to see.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a missing person. Have either of you gentlemen-- (to Tyler) --assuming I can use the word gentleman-- (to both of them) --have you seen him? The cashier takes the photo and looks closely.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: No, I’m afraid I ain’t seen him. Eleanor holds the photo directly in front of Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Have you seen him? Tyler's eyes dart from the photo to Eleanor and back agai

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He ran away from the nursing home where I work at; why, have you seen him?.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Is there a reward?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You a bounty hunter?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Would I be a bounty hunter if I just said there’s no bounty?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Did he kill someone?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What are you then, his sister?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Not that’s it’s any of your business, but I care about him and he’s alone-- Eleanor gathers her things to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: --Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Maybe what?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s alone, or maybe he ain’t alone, you don’t know. Tyler picks up his backpack. What if he’s on a wild adventure and he joined up with a bunch of hitchhikers like something out of a Mark Twain novel? (beat) You like Mark Twain? Eleanor looks Tyler up and down, gun on his back, covered dirt and blood, and begins walking toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I have your phone number?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No. You cannot have my phone number.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: OK, well what if I see your friend there, should I just yell out real loud for you then?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, just do that.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What name do you want me to yell?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Eleanor.  37. Tyler takes another swig from the jug and holds it up for Eleanor in a “cheers” motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler struts out, smile still on his face and passes a wh van labeled “Britthaven Retirement”. He waves to Eleanor and she waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler pushes through the corn to where Zak is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You're a goddamn criminal ain’t ya? Little fugitive... man on the lam. Tyler walks fast as Zak tries to keep pace.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I met your girlfriend Eleanor in there, the cute one from the old folks’ home. She likes you quite a bit got a picture of you and everything. Showing everybody. Zak looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s a good thing as far as I’m concerned. (beat) If we’re gonna make it 70 miles down river we need to have a tie that binds. The fact we are both wanted men is just the kind of tie we needed. Two bandits on the run!

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah! OK!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You do right by me, and I'll do right by you. I said I'll get you to The Salt Water Redneck’s place and I plan to deliver on my word. I’ve been called a lot of bad things in my life, but a liar isn’t one of them. They step out onto a dirt road.  38.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve got two rules though.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: One, don’t slow me down.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: OK, and the other rule? Tyler stops to look at Zak.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I'm in charge. I say “jump” you say “how high?”

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Got it!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Jump. Zak jumps awkwardly a few inches off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. So I say “jump” and then you... Zak jumps again.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just... I’m in charge. You got it? Zak nods, reaches his hand out, and Tyler shakes it. Tyler slips his backpack off and hands it to Zak.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You carry your own weight.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Uhhh... Tyler maybe we should have our own secret handshake.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What kind of secret handshake? For what?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Buds... dudes... Friends. Zak starts making the motions of a unique high five.  39.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Woo hoo ha ha yeah! And then I could spin like this. Zak lifts Tyler's hand up, hits it and spins around wavin his hand like a fish tail. Tyler starts walking again.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: OK, but you can’t be doing that all the time. Only when special shit happens.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Deal. You are in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak approach the water’s edge where the road en Zak looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: It is too far to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, we ain’t got many options. We can’t spend two days scraping through briar bushes and we can’t go back the way we came so we’re gonna swim it. You got any better ideas?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: We could get a plane and then--

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: --Take your pants off.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I can’t swim.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I know you can’t swim but you can float. Tyler takes the pair of pants and ties knots in the knees creates a crude floatation device for Zak. Tyler ties one end of his rope to Zak, feeds 30 feet thro his hands and ties the other end to himself.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That water is almost 25 feet deep. Those pants should hold air just fine, but on the off chance you sink again I don’t want to go down with you, and I sure as hell don’t want to dredge for your body. (beat) This way I can pull you across without being scared of you drowning me. Tyler begins to put the backpack in a large trash bag to protect it from the water.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Do you think I could die?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re gonna die. Just a matter of time. (beat) The real question isn’t whether you'll die or not, it’s will you die with a bunch of good stories for people to tell about you when you're gone, now don’t be a bitch let’s go. Zak swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Tyler swims out first while Zak waits on the shore, he ge out 25 feet and then yells to Zak.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Zak timidly gets in the water and starts gently kicking. Tyler is pulling him while swimming breast stroke. Zak looks like he might sink at any moment if he lost the pants filled with air. This goes on for some time. Tyler's view is slightly blocked by the waves and water. He hears the low deep rumble of an engine. Tyler pops his head up and sees a barge 250 meters away barreling toward them.  41.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Zak begins kicking his legs faster but isn’t making much progress. He submerges in the water and resurfaces. Tyler attempts to swim in full sprint but Zak is dead wei Tyler clears the path of the barge but it continues to be down toward Zak.

dialogues.speaker: USE YOUR LEGS ZAK
dialogues.text: Zak begins to kick a bit harder but still moves slowly. Tyler hits the shore and starts pulling the rope as fast he can, hand-over-hand.

dialogues.speaker: KICK YOUR LEGS DAMN IT
dialogues.text: Zak kicks while Tyler frantically muscles in the rope whi falling backward, he is red and looks like he is going to pass out from exhaustion. The boat barely misses Zak. Tyler falls back onto the ground as Zak, now safe, kicks shore. Tyler breathes hard and looks spent. Zak walks up to him, grabs his hand, and pulls him to his feet fast and hard, demonstrating his great strength. Zak does the secret spinning handshake.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: That is a good story we can tell. Zak starts to walk away but then turns to address Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You coming?

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tyler walks, lost in thought, not nearly as fast as befor After a moment he stops and looks behind him. He sees Zak, who has stopped to watch ants marching in a line. They carry loads ten times their size.  42.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Hey little ants. Hey there. Zak waves and smiles at the ants. Tyler softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zak and Tyler sit on a log at the water's edge. Tyler enters the water and washes off the mud from earlie He motions for Zak to join and begins teaching him to swi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler sits in the sand with his back leaned against a shipwrecked sailboat lit by the moon. Zak lays a few feet away splayed out in the sand. Tyler hand rolls a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MUAH HUAH HUAH HUAH
dialogues.text: Zak lets out an evil cackle that sounds like a cartoon Dracula. He looks to Tyler for approval, who shakes his h “no.”

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I ain’t even the slightest bit scared of you.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: When I’m a professional wrestler I’m going to be a bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Why do you want to be the bad guy? Zak searches for the words.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Because my family left me. This hits Tyler hard.  43.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: That don’t make you the bad guy. Good guys get left too Zak. It’s not about an evil laugh or wearing black. It has nothing to do with that; it has to do with what’s in here. Tyler taps his chest with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got a good guy heart. You can’t do shit about it, that’s just who you are... You’re a hero. Zak thinks on this.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: No, I can’t be a hero because I am a Down syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What’s that got to do with your heart? Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Coach, teachers...

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What’d your coach say?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: He said I am retarded.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Sounds like a shitty coach. Your team ever win anything? Zak looks to Tyler and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s lots of stuff you probably won't do. Like slam dunk a basketball or be an Olympic swimmer. (beat) You sink like a stone, know why? Zak shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because you’re all muscle, and muscle sinks. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today when you pulled me up by the river... the most grown-ass men I know aren’t that strong. You almost took my arm off. Zak smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck your coach. Tyler lights the hand rolled cigarette. A warm glow illuminates his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Tyler, who were the people that chased us in the boat?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Duncan and Ratboy.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Are they good guys or bad guys?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Tyler?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Are you a good guy or a bad guy? Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, what you think?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: You are a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Zak lies quietly and twitches in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin flashback music.  45. Tyler and Mark sit at a bar surrounded by empty beer bott and shot glasses. Mark wears a cowboy hat and a crisp new purple brush popper (western shirt). Mark smiles at Tyler. They talk and connect but no words can be heard. Mark places his hand on the back of Tyler’s neck intimate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Mark get in Mark’s pickup. Tyler is driving. The truck eats up miles on the dark and lonely road. Inside, Mark sleeps while Tyler's eyes get heavy. The truck crosses over the center line, continues off the road... End flashback music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler wakes to find Zak doing push-ups. Zak is grunting and straining to keep form. Tyler sits up, still sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Will you please train me?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Train to be a hero.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You want me to train you?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I had big plans for today. I’m not sure I’1ll have time for that.  46. Zak stares at him waiting for the “yes.”

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I... Uh... Sure... I guess, sure. (beat) You know I don’t know shit about wrestling. Zak shakes his head yes.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok. I'll just like... life train you.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK AND TYLER
dialogues.text: --Zak does push-ups and sit-ups and shoulder presses a la branch. --Tyler throws dry crackers into the water, fish start to at them and Tyler blasts shotgun rounds into the school. --Tyler and Zak eat their catch off of sticks over a fire --They walk the train tracks while Zak bobs and weaves. --Tyler and Zak sit under a tree eating watermelon.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--Eleanor, huh? Zak nods.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s she like?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: She's my friend. She looks out for me. She gives me snacks, and she’s really sweet.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Not so sweet that you wanted to stick around.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: No, not that sweet. --Tyler carves helmets out of the watermelon rind. --They play wrestle in a field. --Tyler puts four beer bottles on sticks 30 yards from wh Zak stands holding the shotgun.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Just point and pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yeah, got it.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Open your stance up a bit. --Zak opens his legs wider.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good, now you look like an athlete. --Zak takes aim and shoots, all the bottles explode into glass shards. --Zak cheers and Tyler smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I hit all of them!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: It’s called buckshot. They do their secret handshake.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK AND TYLER
dialogues.text: INT. ELEANOR’S CAR - DUSK Eleanor looks at a road map with a highlighted line that in Ayden. She marks an X directly on the line where the convenience store was located.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler picks up a beer bottle.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Just keep your eye on the prize. Aim, and pull the trigger. Zak changes his foot position while Tyler isn't looking a places one foot directly next to the other one. Tyler throws the bottle in the air. Zak tracks the bottle through the air, pulls the trigger, hits his target. The kick sends him flying backwards.  48. Tyler runs to see if Zak is OK. Zak stands up, hobbles, and winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You alright bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak slide under a barbed-wire fence and stand a old ovens, broken-down cars, and metal barrels. Zak walks with difficulty, keeping weight off his ankle. Tyler quietly approaches an old 12 foot tin boat and star to pull scrap wood off of it.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: This should work just fine. Zak looks nervous but starts to help Tyler. The distinct sound of a pistol cocks.

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE MUH FUCKAS
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak spin around to see BLIND JASPER JOHN (74), African American man, who has a six-shooter pointed direc at them. His head swivels back and forth like Stevie Wond His eyes have no pigment. They put their hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One gat damn move from either of y'all and I will lay yo asses down. Ya'll trifling muh fuckas think cause ol’ Jasper is blind that you can come robbin’ his ass? Think again! Tyler and Zak are silent.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Y'all boys black or white? Tyler and Zak look at each other not knowing how to respo

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK then. Blind Jasper John blasts a slug past their heads!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak fall to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER ZAK
dialogues.text: Jesus! Wuh wuh wuh, we are white!

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: I knowd y’all was white! I could smell y’all from a mile away! (beat) Y'all God fearing? Tyler and Zak think for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: (Cocks pistol) Matters to me.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Then yes, we are. Blind Jasper John lowers his gun.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: (Sweetens) A friend of Jesus is a friend of Jasper John’s as far as I’m concerned! Lucky for y’all muh fuckas it’s Sunday, and what a blessed day it is to confess some sins.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: What sins are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: Attempted robbery of a blind man seems like a nice place to start.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. WATERFRONT BEHIND BLIND JASPER’S JUNKYARD - DAY Begin “Swing Low Sweet Chariot” <Jasper’s Family Choir> Blind Jasper John is dressed in all white and stands wais deep in water holding a bible; he has the pistol tucked i his pants.  50. Zak and Tyler sit on an old tire and watch on. Jasper’s family is in attendance. Three small African American children all under the age of 5, with their Mother (32) a Grand Mother (64). Tyler looks slightly uncomfortable, but bears with it.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: There are wolves in this world and there are sheep. I might not has my eyes, but I know the difference. And I knows that both you boys are just two weary fleece wearing travelers who have lost y’alls way. Neither of y’all is wolves. Y'all just sheep who have strayed from His flock. Jasper looks to the sky, Tyler swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m donatin’ supplies from my junk yard for your pilgrimage, anything but that tin boat you can has it. Cause I sees it as my duty to get both you sheep back to your Shepard. Tyler and Zak look slightly relieved.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cain’t has you boys runnin off from here with dirt on y’alls hands. A wolf can hunt you down just by the smell of the sins of yo’ past. I don’t want no wolves getting a’hold of you now, cause that would be a frightful bloody mess. (beat) So we gonna clean you up right. (beat) With a baptism.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: (to Tyler) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: It’s like swimming. Zak looks intrigued.  51.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: Both y’all come down here and bathe in the warm waters of forgiveness. Zak limps to the water's edge; he cautiously steps in.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Zak) Today marks the first day of the rest of your life. Nothing can touch you with the good grace of the Lord. (to Tyler) Stand up son, accept His blessing. (beat) Put the wolves of yo’ past to rest. Blind Jasper John’s family all watch in silence.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I’m more of a baptism by fire kind of guy.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, unfortunately I don’t perform those kinds of baptisms. Begin flashback music. cur TO: Zak, arms spread wide, falls backwards in the brown murky river. Blind Jasper John is there to catch him, and holds nose as he slips under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Tyler aggressively collects things around the junkyard Zak helps. Barrels / rope / wood pallets / old bed sheets Tyler's shotgun is peacefully framed in the foreground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Tyler ties the barrels to scraps of wood and then start hammering nails. Close-up on the shotgun where “FAMILY FIRST” is branded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --He takes a dirty sheet and makes a crude sail out of it --Tyler and Zak are building a raft.  52. --They throw extra wood on the platform and then push the raft into the water. Tyler carefully pins the photo of Mark and himself to the crude steering mechanism at the back of the raft. EXT. WATERFRONT BEHIND BLIND JASPER’S JUNKYARD - DAY --Tyler and Zak push the raft along two small pine trees, with their bark shaved off, into the water with a splash. --It looks like trash, but it floats and they look please --Blind Jasper John shakes Tyler’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: OK then, Moses. Fade out flashback music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler sits on the front of the raft with his feet hanging over the edge. His shotgun is resting in his lap. Zak sits next to him, noticing his somber mood. Tyler stares into the silky almost black water. The two sit in silence for a long time. Zak puts his arm around Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Tyler, when I can take care of you, I will. Tyler lets this settle in.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will give you all the wishes for my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Begin flashback music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours down as Mark and Tyler sit side by side with t legs hanging off the end of a boat dock. They laugh and have a conversation but no words can be he End flashback music.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Tyler begins to break down and caves into Zak’s embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor knocks on Jasper’s front door. He answers she holds up a photo of Zak.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Excuse me sir, I was wondering if you've seen--

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: I ain’t seen shit, girl! Eleanor notices the cataracts in Jasper’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you might have heard... Eleanor is searching for the words.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND JASPER JOHN
dialogues.text: You God fearing? Eleanor looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler hops off the raft followed by Zak, who winces in pa when he steps down in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Ouch, my ankle!  54.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You hurt your ankle? Tyler takes a sip of whiskey from the dirty brown jug the hands it to Zak.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, this’1l numb it down. Zak takes the liquor and chugs. Tyler watches and nods his head in approval. Zak smiles at Tyler and hands him back the whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Tyler matches Zak’s chug, gulp for gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zak has his shirt off, he is doing jumping jacks in the s beside a bonfire. The jug of whiskey, noticeably lighter than before, rests near by. Tyler counts reps from a reclined position across the fir
Zak stops doing push-ups, tired now from the effort.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I definitely can not feel my ankle anymore! Or my legs! Or my head! Zak raises his hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: I CAN'T FEEL MY HANDS
dialogues.text: Tyler laughs. Zak swigs the whiskey, then stands and tries to lift a la piece of driftwood laying nearby. He can’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not strong enough.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Who is strong enough?  55. Zak looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t you need, like another name. An alter ego? The Salt Water Redneck wasn’t born with that name.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Are you sure that wasn’t his name when he was born?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Nah, I bet his name was Frank or Beau or something. (beat) If you can’t do it, then who can? Zak thinks on this.

dialogues.speaker: THE FALCON CAN DO IT
dialogues.text: Tyler gets up and walks into the darkness. He comes back with two large branches filled with leaves. He attaches the branches with duct tape to the back of Za body like wings.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: OK. Let’s see it Falcon. Zak tries to lift the driftwood and gets it a little high but fails again. He drops the wood.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: War paint. Zak nods in approval. Tyler grabs some charcoal from around the fire and rubs i Zak's face in four even lines like a warrior football pla Zak smiles. Zak dips his hand in the jar of peanut butter and smears handful on his face to complement the charcoal lines.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: The Peanut Butter Falcon. Tyler smiles.  56.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: The Peanut Butter Falcon.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Tyler and Zak both have war paint on their faces. Zak stands only in his underwear and Peanut Butter Falcon regalia, struggling to get the driftwood lifted. His face is veiny, red, and sweaty, reflecting the fireli Zak yells like a warrior in the throws of battle. Tyler looks on excited and nervous at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: --Zak flips the driftwood into the air and onto the fire sending sparks high into the night sky. --Tyler rips his shirt off and starts screaming at the to his lungs. --Zak flexes his muscles and starts jumping up and down. --They run around the inferno yelling like wild savages. --Zak moves his arms like falcon wings and howls at the m --They do a tribal dance as they spin around the blaze. --The flames rage high into the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zak and Tyler are both passed out on the sand. The fire from the night before smolders. Zak snores soundly, his mouth agape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A van drives down a dirt road toward the thick black trai smoke in the distance.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A van arrives, tires on gravel; a door opens and closes, followed by the chirping sound of a car lock engaging. Footsteps approach, a purse drops onto the ground beside keys on a “Britthaven Retirement” keychain jingle inside. A hand wipes peanut butter off of Zak's face. Eleanor is crouching over him, she looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh Zak, thank God you’re okay. Zak begins to stir and sits up, hungover. Tyler stands fifty yards away peeing into the bay.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tyler) Haven't seen him, huh? Tyler smiles wryly and yells in a low, mocking voice.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: ELEANOR! I FOUND HIM, HE’S RIGHT

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Is that funny to you? You think this is a game? (to Zak) Get up Zak; we are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: He’s not going anywhere. Zak, stay put.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I had to drive for twelve miles down a dirt road to find you, twelve miles and my cell phone battery is dead now! What if there was an emergency? What if he got hurt?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: He did get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to Zak) Are you hurt?!  58.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: My ankle hurts.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Exactly my point! (to Tyler) You've got a boy with Down syndrome out here in the middle of nowhere, doing God knows what!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: He’s not a child, he’s damn near twenty-two years old!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He needs someone to take care of him! Who are you anyway!?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I’m the guy taking care of him because you can’t do it without keeping him in a cage.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That’s cute. So you two are in some sort of primitive gang?! This isn’t Lord of The Flies! There are rules and regulations and red tape and paperwork--

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: While you were talking about eventually doing some paperwork we were doing a little thing called living.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Living?! You call this living!? You two look like cave men! Tyler and Zak look at each other and take in their bodies unkempt, stinky, dirty, half naked, covered in peanut but and soot. They both grin.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I know. It’s awesome.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: It really is awesome, Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Get up, Zak! Zak starts to stand up.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Stay where you’re at, Zak! Zak sits down.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) Can I talk to you in private for a moment? Tyler grabs Eleanor’s arm and walks her away from where Z is sitting.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I should have you arrested for kidnapping!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: You can’t kidnap someone who ran away, genius.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: This isn’t some--

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: What do you want for Zak?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m not going to sell him to you!

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: No, what do you WANT FOR Zak? For his life.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m taking Zak with me.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: No you’re not. (beat) Do you know about the wrestling thing?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How do you think I found you?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I made him a promise to get him to that wrestling school, and I don’t break my promises. I see you care about Zak, so I’1l do you a favor. You can ride on the raft with us, that way you can watch out for him. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TYLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm getting him to that wrestling school with or without you. What happens after that... well, that’s your business.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No. I have to go back to work. I’ve got my hours to account for, I can’t just get on your little raft and disappear.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you. At the campfire, Zak takes the keys out of Eleanor’s purs

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Hey, Eleanor! Eleanor and Tyler both turn toward Zak as he throws her k far into the deep murky water. There is a comically long pause as Tyler and Eleanor watc Zak in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go back. (beat) I’m going to meet the Salt Water Redneck! Eleanor turns back to Tyler and continues to negotiate ev though she has no other options.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That's it. That’s all you get. The wrestling school and that’s the end for you.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: It’s not for me. Eleanor looks to Zak who is doing a celebratory dance, an softens.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: After that I take him back with me and this becomes a memory.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Whatever, but till then, you give me all of him.  61.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (hesitant) OK. (beat) He goes home with me in the end. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor sits on the raft, arms crossed, looking unhappy. quiet and tense and the sheet they use for a sail is not catching any wind. Zak stands up and starts blowing into the sail.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How far is it on the raft?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: On the map, it’s about this far. (pinches his fingers)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Is that one day?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Well... tide and wind matter, a day or, you know, two.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Zak, why don’t you sit down, you'll get dizzy breathing that hard, and slip and hurt yourself. Tyler shakes his head, frustrated by Eleanor. Zak sits.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you hungry, Zak? Did you have breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: I’m not really hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: OK, well, maybe you should just have a bite of something--

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Don’t do that.  62.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? Tyler thinks.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (to Zak) Eleanor’s right, we should work on your breath control. Just cause we're on a raft doesn’t mean we can’t train, right?

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Oh Tyler, that is very smart.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Lean over the edge of the raft and put your head under water. I’11l time you.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) He CAN stand up on a raft, he CAN feed himself, and he CAN hold his breath while he’s training to be a wrestler.

dialogues.speaker: ZAK
dialogues.text: Yes I can! Tyler nods to Zak and Zak nods back. Zak places his head underwater, unable to hear the conversation that continues above.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Stop calling Zak a retard.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I have never used that word in my life.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Might as well have, they way you treat him. You--
